question: Question 1 A real square matrix A is called skew-symmetric if
solution: A is skew-symmetric [latex] \therefore \quad A^{T}=-A[/latex]

question: Question 2 [latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{log_{e}(1+4x)}{e^{3x}-1}[/latex]   is equal to
solution: [latex]\lim_{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (1+4 x)}{e^{3 x}-1} [/latex] [latex] \lim_{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\frac{1}{1+4 x} \cdot 4}{3 e^{3 x}}=\frac{4}{3}[/latex]

question: Question 3 Solutions of Laplace's equation having continuous second-order partial derivatives are called
solution: Solution of laplace equation having continuous Second order partial derivating [latex] \therefore \nabla^{2} \phi =0 [/latex] [latex] \frac{\partial^{2} \phi}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} \phi}{\partial y^{2}} =0[/latex] [latex] \therefore \; \phi[/latex] is harmonic function.

question: Question 4 The area (in percentage) under standard normal distribution curve of random variable Z within limits from -3 to +3  is __________
Question 5 The root of the function [latex]f(x)=x^{3}+x-1[/latex] obtained after first iteration on application of NewtonRaphson scheme using an initial guess of [latex]x_{0}=1[/latex] is
Question 6 A force F is acting on a bent bar which is clamped at one end as shown in the figure. The CORRECT free body diagram is
solution: When we draw a free body diagram we remove all the supports and force applied due to that support are drawn and force or moment will apply in that manner so that it resists forces in any direction as well as any tendency of rotation. Option (B) is wrong because the ground should not be shown in FBD as the forces due to ground are already depicted. Option (C) is wrong because x-component is not shown. Option (D) is wrong because the rotation due to the force acting eccentrically causes moment which is not shown.

question: Question 7 The cross-sections of two solid bars made of the same material are shown in the figure. The square cross-section has flexural (bending) rigidity I1, while the circular cross-section has flexural rigidity I2. Both sections have the same cross-sectional area. The ratio I1/I2 is
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad b^{2}&=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{b^{2}}{d^{2}}&=\frac{\pi}{4} \\ I_{1} &=\frac{b^{4}}{12} \\ I_{2} &=\frac{\pi d^{4}}{64} \\ \therefore \qquad \frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}} &=\frac{b^{4}}{12} \times \frac{64}{\pi d^{4}}=\frac{16}{3 \pi} \frac{b^{4}}{d^{4}} \\ &=\frac{16}{3 \pi} \cdot \frac{\pi^{2}}{16}=\frac{\pi}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 8 The state of stress at a point on an element is shown in figure (a). The same state of stress is shown in another coordinate system in figure (b). The components ([latex]\tau _{xx},\tau _{yy},\tau _{xy}[/latex])  are given by
solution: The given plane is principal plane [latex] \left(\sigma_{1}=P, \sigma_{2}=-P\right) [/latex]. At [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex] from principal plane, plane of max shear occurs. On the plane of max shear. [latex] \begin{aligned} \operatorname{both}, \quad \tau_{x y} &=\tau_{y y}=\frac{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}}{2}=0 \\ \tau_{x y} &=\frac{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}}{2}=P \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 9 A rigid link PQ is undergoing plane motion as shown in the figure ([latex]V_{P}[/latex] and [latex]V_{Q}[/latex] are non-zero). [latex]V_{PQ}[/latex] is the relative velocity of point Q with respect to point P. Which one of the following is TRUE?
solution: To find relative velocity direction of [latex] V_{p} [/latex] is reversed and placed at fail of  [latex]\vec{V}_{Q} [/latex] Ans. (D) Resultant [latex] V_{PQ}[/latex]  is perpendicular to link  P  Q.

options.A: [latex]V_{PQ}[/latex]  has components along and perpendicular to PQ
options.B: [latex]V_{PQ}[/latex]  has only one component directed from P to Q
options.C: [latex]V_{PQ}[/latex]  has only one component directed from Q to P
options.D: [latex]V_{PQ}[/latex]  has only one component perpendicular to PQ

question: Question 10 The number of degrees of freedom in a planar mechanism having n links and j simple hinge joints is
solution: Degrees of freedom is given by 3(n-1) - 2j

question: Question 11 The static deflection of a spring under gravity, when a mass of 1 kg is suspended from it, is 1 mm. Assume the acceleration due to gravity g =10 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]. The natural frequency of this spring-mass system (in rad/s) is_____________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} g=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ m=1 \mathrm{kg}\\ \text{Deflection:}\; \Delta=1 \mathrm{mm} \\ \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\Delta}}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{1 \times 10^{-3}}}=100 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 12 Which of the bearings given below SHOULD NOT be subjected to a thrust load?
solution: Correct option is (C)

question: Question 13 A channel of width 450 mm branches into two sub-channels having width 300 mm and 200 mm as shown in figure. If the volumetric flow rate (taking unit depth) of an incompressible flow through the main channel is 0.9 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s and the velocity in the sub-channel of width 200 mm is 3 m/s, the velocity in the sub-channel of width 300 mm is _____________ m/s. Assume both inlet and outlet to be at the same elevation.
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} b_{1}&=450 \mathrm{mm}=0.45 \mathrm{m} \\ b_{2}&=300 \mathrm{mm}=0.30 \mathrm{m} \\ b_{3}&=200 \mathrm{mm}=0.20 \mathrm{m} Depth: \quad h&=1 \mathrm{m} \\ Q_{1}&=0.9 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{3}&=3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{2}&=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Apply equation of continuity, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{1}&=Q_{2}+Q_{3}\\ Q_{1}&=A_{2} V_{2}+A_{3} V_{3} \\ Q_{1}&=b_{2} h V_{2}+b_{3} h V_{3} \\ 0.9&=0.30 \times 1 \times V_{2}+0.20 \times 1 \times 3 \\ 0.9&=0.30 \mathrm{V}_{2}+0.60\\ or \quad 0.30 \mathrm{V}_{2}&=0.9-0.6=0.30 \\ or\qquad v_{2}=\frac{0.30}{0.30}&=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 14 For a certain two-dimensional incompressible flow, velocity field is given by  [latex]2xy\hat{i}-y^{2}\hat{j}[/latex]. The streamlines for this flow are given by the family of curves
solution: [latex]\vec{v}=2 x y \hat{i}-y^{2} \hat{j}[/latex] where  [latex]u=2 x y[/latex] and [latex]v=-y^{2} [/latex] Equation of stream line, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d x}{u} &=\frac{d y}{v} \\ \frac{d x}{2 x y} &=\frac{d y}{-y^{2}} \\ \text{or}\quad \frac{d x}{2 x} &=-\frac{d y}{y} \end{aligned}[/latex] On integrating, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} \log _{e} x&=-\log _{e} y+\log _{e} c \\ \log _{e} x^{1 / 2}+\log _{e} y&=\log _{e} c \\ \log _{e} x^{1 / 2} y&=\log _{e} c \\ \text { or } \quad x^{1 / 2} y&=c \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 Steady one-dimensional heat conduction takes place across the faces 1 and 3 of a composite slab consisting of slabs A and B in perfect contact as shown in the figure, where [latex]k_{A},k_{B}[/latex] denote the respective thermal conductivities. Using the data as given in the figure, the interface temperature  T2 (in [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]) is __________
solution: At steady state [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{A} &=Q_{B} \\ \frac{k_{A}\left[T_{1}-T_{2}\right] A}{L_{1}} &=\frac{k_{B}\left[T_{2}-T_{3}\right] A}{L_{2}} \\ \frac{20 \times\left[130-T_{2}\right]}{0.1} &=\frac{100 \times\left[T_{2}-30\right]}{0.3} \\ 3\left[130-T_{2}\right] &=5 T_{2}-150 \\ 390-3 T_{2} &=5 T_{2}-150 \\ 540 &=8 T_{2} \\ T_{2} &=67.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 16 Grashof number signifies the ratio of
solution: Grashof number is ratio of buoyancy force to viscous force.

options.D: inertia force to surface tension force

question: Question 17 The INCORRECT statement about the characteristics of critical point of a pure substance is that
solution: At critical point liquid directly converts vapour phase.

options.A: there is no constant temperature vaporization process
options.B: it has point of inflection with zero slope
options.C: the ice directly converts from solid phase to vapor phase
options.D: saturated liquid and saturated vapor states are identical

question: Question 18 For a heat exchanger, [latex]\Delta T_{max}[/latex] is the maximum temperature difference and [latex]\Delta T_{min}[/latex] is the minimum temperature difference between the two fluids. LMTD is the log mean temperature difference. [latex]C_{min}[/latex] and[latex]C_{max}[/latex] are the minimum and the maximum heat capacity rates. The maximum possible heat transfer ([latex]Q_{max}[/latex]) between the two fluids is
solution: Maximum heat transfer possible [latex] =C_{\min } \times(\Delta T)_{\max }[/latex]

question: Question 19 The blade and fluid velocities for an axial turbine are as shown in the figure. The magnitude of absolute velocity at entry is 300 m/s at an angle of [latex]65^{\circ}[/latex] to the axial direction, while the magnitude of the absolute velocity at exit is 150 m/s. The exit velocity vector has a component in the downward direction. Given that the axial (horizontal) velocity is the same at entry and exit, the specific work (in kJ/kg) is__________
solution: Given data: Axial (horizontal) velocity is the same at entry and exit. [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{1}=300 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \theta_{1}=65^{\circ} \\ V_{2}=150 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}, u=150 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Given condition, [latex] V_{1} \cos 65^{\circ}=V_{2} \cos \theta_{0}[/latex] [latex] 300 \cos 65^{\circ}=150 \times \cos \theta_{0}[/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad\cos \theta_{0}=0.8452 [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad \theta_{0}=32.30^{\circ}[/latex] Specific work, [latex] \begin{aligned} w &=\left[V_{1} \sin 65^{\circ}-\left(-V_{2} \sin 32.30^{\circ}\right)\right] u \\ &=\left[300 \sin 65^{\circ}+150 \sin 32.30^{\circ}\right]\times150 \\ &=52806.77 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg} \\ &=52.80 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 Engineering strain of a mild steel sample is recorded as 0.100%. The true strain is
solution: Given data Engineering strain, [latex] \begin{aligned} \epsilon &=0.100 \%=0.001 \\ \text { True strain : } \bar{\epsilon} &=\ln (1+\epsilon) \\ &=\ln (1+0.001) \\ &=0.00099=0.099 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 21 Equal amounts of a liquid metal at the same temperature are poured into three moulds made of steel, copper and aluminum. The shape of the cavity is a cylinder with 15 mm diameter. The size of the moulds are such that the outside temperature of the moulds do not increase appreciably beyond the atmospheric temperature during solidification.  The sequence of solidification in the mould from the fastest to slowest is (Thermal conductivities of steel, copper and aluminum are 60.5, 401 and 237 W/m-K, respectively. Specific heats of steel, copper and aluminum are 434, 385 and 903 J/kg-K, respectively. Densities of steel, copper and aluminum are 7854, 8933 and 2700 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex], respectively.)
solution: Solidification time is inversely proportional to diffusivity and based on the values diffusivity is highest for copper, next is aluminum and then steel. Hence the solidification time is lowest for copper, next aluminum and then steel.

question: Question 22 In a wire-cut EDM process the necessary conditions that have to be met for making a successful cut are that
solution: In a wire-cut EDM process, a thin metallic wire is fed on to the conducting workpiece, which is submerged in a tank of dielectric fluid such as de-ionized water. Wire is fed in the programmed path & material is cut from the workpiece accordingly. Material removal takes place by a series of discrete discharges between the wire electrode & workpiece in the presence of a dielectric fluid. The di-electric fluid gets ionized in between the tool electrode gap thereby creating a  path for each discharge. The area wherein discharge takes place gets heated to very high temperature such that the surface get melted & removed. The cut particles (debris) get flushed away by continuous flowing dielectric fluid. Generally, wire-cut EDM is used for cutting Aluminium, brass, etc. & wire material used for quicker cutting action is zinc coated brass wires.

options.A: wire and sample are electrically non-conducting
options.B: wire and sample are electrically conducting
options.C: wire is electrically conducting and sample is electrically non-conducting
options.D: sample is electrically conducting and wire is electrically non-conducting

question: Question 23 Internal gears are manufactured by
solution: Internal gears are manufactured by gear Broaching and shaping with pinion cutter only, whereas shaping with pinion cutter is used for both external and internal gears.

question: Question 24 Match the following part programming codes with their respective functions
solution: G01 is used for linear interpolation, G03 is used for circular interpolation counter clockwise, M03 for spindle rotation clockwise and M05 for spindle top.

options.A: P- II, Q- I, R- IV, S- III
options.B: P- IV, Q- II, R- III, S- I
options.C: P- IV, Q- III, R- II, S- I
options.D: P- III, Q- IV, R- II, S- I

question: Question 25 In PERT chart, the activity time distribution is
solution: Activity time distribution is beta.

question: Question 26 The number of linearly independent eigenvectors of matrix [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 2 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is  _________
solution: Consider [latex] A-\lambda I=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}2-\lambda & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2-\lambda & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 3-\lambda\end{array}\right] [/latex] Ch. equation is [latex] |A-\lambda I|=0 [/latex] [latex] (2-\lambda)(2-\lambda)(3-\lambda)=0 [/latex] [latex] \lambda=2,2,3 [/latex] [latex] \lambda=3 [/latex] there is one L.I. Eigen vector [latex] \lambda=2 \quad [/latex]Consider [latex] (A-2 I) x=0 [/latex] [latex] \text{rank} =2 \quad [/latex] The equation are [latex] x_{2}=0 [/latex] No. of variables [latex] =3 x_{3}=0 [/latex] Let [latex] x_{1}=k [/latex] be independent. [latex] \therefore \text{Eigen vector is}\; \left[\begin{array}{l}k \\ 0 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=k\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{array}\right] [/latex] Only one independent Eigen vector in the case of [latex] \lambda=2 [/latex] Hence finally no. of L.I. Eigen vectors =2

question: Question 27 The value of the line integral [latex]\oint_{c}\bar{F}\cdot \bar{r'} \; ds[/latex] ,where C is a circle of radius [latex]4/\sqrt{\pi}[/latex] unit is ___ Here, [latex]\bar{F}(x,y)= y\hat{i}+2x\hat{j} \; and \; \bar{r}'[/latex] is the UNIT tangent vector on the curve C at an arc length s from a reference point on the curve. [latex]\hat{i}[/latex]  and [latex]\hat{j}[/latex] are the basis vectors in the x-y Cartesian reference. In evaluating the line integral, the curve has to be traversed in the counter-clockwise direction.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{c} \bar{F} \cdot \vec{r}\acute{} d x=\int_{c} \bar{F} \cdot & d \bar{r}=\int_{c} F_{1} d x+F_{2} d y \\ &=\iint_{R}\left(\frac{\partial F_{2}}{d x}-\frac{\partial F_{1}}{d y}\right) d x d y \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &\begin{array}{l} \begin{array}{rl} F_{1}=y & F_{2}=2 x \\ & =\iint_{R}(2-1) d x d y \end{array} \\ \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial y}=1 \quad \frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial x} &=2 \\ &=\iint d x d y \end{aligned} \end{array}\\ &=\text { Area of the circle with radius } \frac{4}{\sqrt{\pi}}=\pi\left(\frac{4}{\sqrt{\pi}}\right)^{2}\\ &=\pi \frac{16}{\pi}=16 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 [latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\sqrt{x^2+x-1}-x[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\lim\sqrt{x^{2}+x-1}-x [/latex] [latex] \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(\sqrt{x^{2}+x-1}-x)(\sqrt{x^{2}+x-1}+x)}{\sqrt{x^{2}+x-1}+x} [/latex] [latex] \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x^{2}+x-1-x^{2}}{\sqrt{x^{2}+x+1}+x} [/latex] [latex] \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x-1}{x \sqrt{1+\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}}+x} [/latex] [latex] \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1-\frac{1}{x}}{\sqrt{1+\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}+1}}=\frac{1}{1+1}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 29 Three cards were drawn from a pack of 52 cards. The probability that they are a king, a queen, and a jack is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{4_{C_{1}} \cdot 4_{C_{1}} \cdot 4_{C_{1}}}{52_{C_{3}}} &=\frac{64}{\frac{52 \times 51 \times 50}{3 \times 2 \times 1}} \\ &=\frac{64}{22,100}=\frac{16}{5525} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 An inextensible massless string goes over a frictionless pulley. Two weights of 100 N and 200 N are attached to the two ends of the string. The weights are released from rest, and start moving due to gravity. The tension in the string (in N) is __________
solution: Tension in string [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left[\frac{2 m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right] g \\ &=\left[\frac{2 \times \frac{100}{g} \times \frac{200}{g}}{\frac{100}{g}+\frac{200}{g}}\right] g \\ &=\left[\frac{\frac{2 \times 100 \times 200}{g^{2}}}{\frac{(100+200)}{g}}\right] \times g \\ &=\frac{2 \times 100 \times 200}{300} \\ &=\frac{400}{3}=133.33 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 A circular disc of radius 100 mm and mass 1 kg, initially at rest at position  A, rolls without slipping down a curved path as shown in figure. The speed v of the disc when it reaches position B is _________ m/s. Acceleration due to gravity g = 10 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex].
solution: Loss in P.E. = Gain in rotational K . E + gain in translational K.E. [latex] \begin{aligned} m g H &=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \\ v &=r \omega \\ \omega &=\frac{v}{r} \\ m g H &=\frac{1}{2} \frac{m r^{2}}{2} \times\left(\frac{v}{r}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \\ 10 \times 30 &=\frac{v^{2}}{4}+\frac{v^{2}}{2} \\ 10 \times 30 \times 4 &=v^{2}+2 v^{2} \\ 3 v^{2} &=30 \times 10 \times 4 \\ v^{2} &=400 \\ \text{or} \qquad v &=20 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 A rigid rod (AB) of length [latex]L=\sqrt{2}[/latex] m is undergoing translational as well as rotational motion in the x-y plane (see the figure). The point A has the velocity [latex]V_{1}=(\hat{i}+2\hat{j}) m/s[/latex]  The end B is constrained to move only along the x direction The magnitude of the velocity [latex]V_{2}[/latex]  (in m/s) at the end B is __________
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \sqrt{2} \sin 45^{\circ} &=1 \mathrm{m} \\ \tan \theta &=\frac{1}{2} \\ \theta &=\tan ^{-1} 0.5=26.5651^{\circ} \\ \alpha &=90^{\circ}-\left(45^{\circ}+\theta\right)=18.4349^{\circ} \\ \beta &=90^{\circ}-\left(45^{\circ}+\alpha\right)=26.5651^{\circ} \\ \frac{V_{A}}{I_{A}} &=\frac{V_{B}}{I_{B}} \\ V_{B} &=\frac{V_{A} \cdot I_{B}}{I_{A}}=\sqrt{5} \\ \cos \beta &=\frac{1}{I_{A}} \\ I_{A} &=\frac{1}{\cos 26.5651}=1.118 \mathrm{m} \\ I_{C} &=\sqrt{\left(I_{A}\right)^{2}-1^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{(1.118)^{2}-1}=0.5 \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{V_{A}}{I_{A}} &=\frac{V_{B}}{I_{B}} \\ V_{B} &=\frac{\sqrt{3} \times[1+0.5]}{1.118}=3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 A square plate of dimension  L x L is subjected to a uniform pressure load p = 250 MPa on its edges as shown in the figure. Assume plane stress conditions. The Young's modulus E = 200 GPa. The deformed shape is a square of dimension [latex]L-2\delta[/latex] . If L= 2 m  and  [latex]\delta[/latex]=0.001 m, the Poisson's ratio of the plate material is __________
solution: Strain in horizontal direction [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{-2 \delta}{L}=\frac{-P}{E}+\mu \frac{P}{E} \\ \frac{-2 \delta}{L} E=P(-1+\mu) \Rightarrow \frac{-2 \delta E}{L P}=1-\mu \\ \therefore \quad \mu=1-\frac{-2 \delta E}{L P} \\ =1-\frac{2 \times 0.001 \times 200 \times 10^{3}}{2 \times 250}=1-0.8=0.2 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 34 Two circular shafts made of same material, one solid (S) and one hollow (H), have the same length and polar moment of inertia. Both are subjected to same torque. Here,  [latex]\theta_{s}[/latex] is the twist and [latex]\tau_{s}[/latex] is the maximum shear stress in the solid shaft, whereas [latex]\theta_{H}[/latex] is the twist and [latex]\tau_{H}[/latex] is the maximum shear stress in the hollow shaft. Which one of the following is TRUE?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_s=L_H, & T_s=T_H=T,\\ I_{ps} &=I_{pH}\\ \therefore \; \frac{\pi}{32}d^4&=\frac{\pi}{32}(d_o^4-d_i^4)\\ \therefore \; d_o & \gt d\\ \therefore \;r_o &\ gt r\\ \text{Angle of twist}\\ \theta &=\frac{TL}{GI_p}\\ \therefore \; \theta _s&=\theta _H\\ \tau _{max_s}&=\frac{I}{I_p}r\\ \tau _{max_H}&=\frac{I}{I_p}r_o\\ \therefore \; \tau _{max_H}& \gt \tau _{max_s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 A beam of length L is carrying a uniformly distributed load w per unit length. The flexural rigidity of the beam is EI. The reaction at the simple support at the right end is
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta_{B} &=0 \\ \frac{W L^{4}}{8 E I}-\frac{R L^{3}}{3 E I} &=0 \\ \therefore\quad R&=\frac{3 W L}{8} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 Two masses m are attached to opposite sides of a rigid rotating shaft in the vertical plane. Another pair of equal masses m1 is attached to the opposite sides of the shaft in the vertical plane as shown in figure. Consider m = 1 kg, e = 50 mm, e1 = 20 mm, b = 0.3 m, a = 2 m and a1 = 2.5 m. For the system to be dynamically balanced, m1 should be ________ kg.
solution: Balance moment of all forces [latex] \begin{array}{c} \omega^{2}\left(m_{1} \times 0.02 \times 2.5\right)+(1 \times 0.05 \times 0.3) \omega^{2}=\left(m_{1} \times\right. \\ 0.02 \times 0) \omega^{2}+(1 \times 0.05 \times 2.3) \omega^{2} \\ m_{1}=2 \mathrm{kg} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 37 A single degree of freedom spring-mass system is subjected to a harmonic force of constant amplitude. For an excitation frequency of [latex]\sqrt{3k/m}[/latex] the ratio of the amplitude of steady state response to the static deflection of the spring is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{A}{x_{0}} &=\text { Magnification factor } \\ \frac{A}{F_{0} / k} &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\omega}{w_{n}}\right)^{2}+\left(2 \zeta \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}}} \\ \because \qquad \zeta &=0 \\ \frac{A}{F_{0} / k} &=\frac{1}{\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}-1} \\ \omega &=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}}, \quad \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} \\ \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}} &=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} \times \sqrt{\frac{m}{k}} \\ &=\sqrt{3} \\ \frac{A}{F_{0} / k} &=\frac{1}{(\sqrt{3})^{2}-1}=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 A bolted joint has four bolts arranged as shown in figure. The cross sectional area of each bolt is  25[latex]mm^{2}[/latex]. A torque T = 200 N-m is acting on the joint. Neglecting friction due to clamping force, maximum shear stress in a bolt is ______ MPa.
solution: [latex] \therefore \quad P_{1} \times r+P_{2} r+P_{3} r+P_{4} r-T=0 [/latex] [latex] P_{1}=P_{2}=P_{3}=P_{4} \qquad [By symmetry] [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 4 P r&=T \\ P=& \frac{T}{4 r}=\frac{200}{4 \times \frac{50}{1000}}=1000 \mathrm{N} \\ \text { Shear stress } &=\frac{T}{\text { Area }}=\frac{1000}{25}=40 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 Consider a fully developed steady laminar flow of an incompressible fluid with viscosity [latex]\mu[/latex] through a circular pipe of radius R. Given that the velocity at a radial location of R/2 from the centerline of the pipe is [latex]U_{1}[/latex], the shear stress at the wall is [latex]K\mu U_{1}/R[/latex], where K is __________
solution: Shear stress at the wall, [latex] \tau_{0}=\tau_{\max }=\frac{k \mu U_{1}}{R}[/latex] We know that the velocity at any point for laminar flow through pipe, [latex] \begin{aligned} u&=-\frac{1}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right)\left(R^{2}-r^{2}\right)\\ \mathrm{At} \quad r&=\frac{R}{2}, u=U_{1}\\ \therefore \quad U_{1} &=-\frac{1}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right)\left(R^{2}-\frac{R^{2}}{4}\right) \\ &=-\frac{1}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) \frac{3}{4} R^{2} \\ &=-\frac{3}{16 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) R^{2}\\ \therefore \tau_{0}&=-\frac{K \mu}{R} \times \frac{3}{16 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) R^{2}\\ \tau_{0}&=-\frac{3}{16} K\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) R\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that maximum shear stress at wall. [latex] \tau_{0}=-\frac{R \partial p}{\partial} \frac{\partial p}{\partial x}[/latex] [latex] \therefore-\frac{3}{16} K\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) R=-\frac{R}{2} \frac{\partial p}{\partial x} [/latex] [latex] \text{or}K=\frac{8}{3}=2.66[/latex]

question: Question 40 The water jet exiting from a stationary tank through a circular opening of diameter 300 mm impinges on a rigid wall as shown in the figure. Neglect all minor losses and assume the water level in the tank to remain constant. The net horizontal force experienced by the wall is ___________ kN. Density of water is 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. Acceleration due to gravity g = 10 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex].
solution: Diameter of jet, [latex] d = 300\mathrm{mm} = 0.30 \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad [/latex]Cross-section area, [latex] \begin{aligned} a &=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2}=\frac{3.14}{4} \times(0.30)^{2} \\ &=0.07065 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \text{Jet Velocity: }V \;&=\sqrt{2 g h}\\ &=\sqrt{2 \times 10 \times 6.2} = 11.135\mathrm{m}/\mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Net horizontal force [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=m[V-0] \\ &=\rho a V \times V \\ &=\rho a V^{2} \\ &=1000 \times 0.07065 \times(11.135)^{2} \\ &=8759.76 \mathrm{N} \\ &=8.76 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 For a two-dimensional flow, the velocity field is [latex]\vec{u}=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\hat{i}+\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\hat{j}[/latex], where [latex]\hat{i}[/latex]  and [latex]\hat{j}[/latex]  are the basis vectors in the x-y Cartesian coordinate system. Identify the CORRECT statements from below. (1)The flow is incompressible (2)The flow is unsteady. (3) y-component of acceleration, [latex]a_{y}=\frac{-y}{(x^{2}+y^{2})^{2}}[/latex] (4)  x-component of acceleration,[latex]a_{x}=\frac{-(x+y)}{(x^{2}+y^{2})^{2}}[/latex]
solution: For [latex]2 \mathrm{D}[/latex] -flow velocity field is: [latex] \begin{aligned} \vec{V}&=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \hat{i}+\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \hat{j}\\ so \quad u&=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} and v=\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \\ a_{x} &=u \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+v \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \\ &=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right] \\ &+\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left[\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right] \\ &= \frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\left[\frac{x(-2 x)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right]\\ &+\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \left[\frac{x(2 y)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}\right]\\ &=\frac{-2 x^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}+\frac{x}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}\\ &+ \frac{2xy^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}\\ &=\frac{-2 x^{3}+x\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)-2 x y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \\ &=\frac{-2 x^{3}+x^{3}+x y^{2}-2 x y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}\\ &=\frac{-x^{3}-x y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \\ &=\frac{-x\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} a_{x} &=\frac{x}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}} \\ a_{y} &=u \frac{\partial v}{\partial x}+u \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \\ &=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right] \\& +\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left[\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right] \\ &=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{(-2 x y)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}\\& +\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \times\left[\frac{-2 y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right]\\ &=\frac{-2 x^{2} y}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}+\frac{2 y^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}\\&+\frac{y}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}} \\ &=\frac{-2 x^{2} y-2 y^{3}+y\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \\ &=\frac{-x^{2} y-y^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}=\frac{y\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \\ a_{y}&=\frac{-y}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 Two large parallel plates having a gap of 10 mm in between them are maintained at temperatures  T1 = 1000 K and T2 = 400 K. Given emissivity values, [latex]\varepsilon{1}=0.5[/latex] ,  [latex]\varepsilon_{2}=0.25[/latex]  and Stefan-Boltzmann constant [latex]\sigma= 5.67 \times 10^{-8} W/m^{2}-K^{4}[/latex], the heat transfer between the plates (in kW/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) is __________ _________
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=\frac{\sigma\left[T_{1}^{4}-T_{2}^{4}\right]}{\frac{1}{\epsilon_{1}}+\frac{1}{\epsilon_{2}}-1}=\frac{5.67 \times 10^{-8} \times\left(1000^{4}-400^{4}\right)}{\frac{1}{0.5}+\frac{1}{0.25}-1} \\ &=11049.7 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}=11.05 \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A cylindrical steel rod, 0.01 m in diameter and 0.2 m in length is first heated to [latex]750^{\circ}C[/latex]  and then immersed in a water bath at [latex]100^{\circ}C[/latex] .  The heat transfer coefficient is 250 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]-K. The density, specific heat and thermal conductivity of steel are [latex]\rho = 7801 kg/m^{3}[/latex], c = 473 J/kg-K, and  k = 43 W/m-K, respectively.  The time required for the rod to reach [latex]300^{\circ}C[/latex]  is ________  seconds.
solution: Given data: [latex] \mathrm{D}=0.01 \mathrm{m} ; \quad L=0.2 \mathrm{m} ; \quad T_{i}=750^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] [latex] T_{\infty}=100^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad h=250 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} ; \quad \rho=7801 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{c}=473 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T-T_{\infty}}{T_{i}-T_{\infty}}&=\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{h A t}{\rho V c}}\\\text{ Where }\quad \frac{V}{A}&=\frac{\pi D^{2} L}{4 \times \pi D L}=\frac{D}{4}=\frac{0.01}{4} \\ &=2.5 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \frac{300-100}{750-100}&=e^{\frac{-250 \times t}{7801 \times 2.5 \times 10^{-3} \times 473}} \\ \frac{200}{650}&=e^{-0.0271 t} \\ 0.30769&=e^{-0.0271 t}\end{aligned}[/latex] Taking [latex]  \log _{e} [/latex] both sides, we get [latex]\begin{aligned}  \log _{e} 0.30769&=-0.0271 t \log _{e} e \\ &\qquad\left(\because \log _{\theta} e=1\right) \\ t&=\frac{1.1786}{0.027}=43.65 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 Steam at an initial enthalpy of 100 kJ/kg and inlet velocity of 100 m/s, enters an insulated horizontal nozzle. It leaves the nozzle at 200 m/s. The exit enthalpy (in kJ/kg) is __________
solution: Applying steady flow energy equation between section 1 and 2. [latex] h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2}+g z_{1}+q=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2}+g_{2}+w [/latex] where q=0 insulated nozzle [latex] z_{1}=z_{2} \quad[/latex] horizontal nozzle w=0  always for nozzle [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2} &=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2} \\ h_{1}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2000} &=h_{2}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2000} \end{aligned}[/latex] where [latex] h_{1}[/latex] and [latex]h_{2}[/latex] are in kJ/kg and [latex]V_{1}[/latex] and [latex]V_{2}[/latex] are in m/s [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore 100+\frac{(100)^{2}}{2000} &=h_{2}+\frac{(200)^{2}}{2000} \\ 100+5 &=h_{2}+20 \\ \text{or}\quad h_{2} &=85 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 In a mixture of dry air and water vapor at a total pressure of 750 mm of Hg, the partial pressure of water vapor is 20 mm of Hg. The humidity ratio of the air in grams of water vapor per kg of dry air  ([latex]g_{w}/kg_{da}[/latex]) is __________
solution: Given data: Total pressure, [latex] p=750 \mathrm{mm} \text { of } \mathrm{Hg}[/latex] Partial pressure, [latex] p_{v}=20 \mathrm{mm} \text { of } \mathrm{Hg}[/latex] We know that humidity ratio, [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega &=\frac{0.622 p_{v}}{p-p_{v}} \mathrm{kg} w.v./ \mathrm{kg} d.a. \\ &=\frac{0.622 \times 20}{750-20} \\ &=0.01704 \;\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{w} . \mathrm{v} . \mathrm{kg} \text { of } \mathrm{d.a} \\ &=17.04 \;\mathrm{g} \text { of } \mathrm{w} . \mathrm{v} . / \mathrm{kg} \text { of } \mathrm{d.a} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 In a 3-stage air compressor, the inlet pressure is [latex]p_{1}[/latex], discharge pressure is [latex]p_{4}[/latex] and the intermediate pressures are [latex]p_{2}[/latex] and [latex]p_{3}[/latex] ( [latex]p_{2}\lt p_{3}[/latex]). The total pressure ratio of the compressor is 10 and the pressure ratios of the stages are equal. If [latex]p_{1}[/latex] = 100 kPa, the value of the pressure [latex]p_{3}[/latex] (in kPa) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{p_{4}}{p_{1}}&=10 \\ \frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}&=\frac{p_{3}}{p_{2}}=\frac{p_{4}}{p_{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] To calculate [latex]p_{3}=? [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{p_{4}}{p_{3}} \times \frac{p_{3}}{p_{2}} \times \frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}&=10 \\ r_{p} \times r_{p} \times r_{p}&=10 \\ r_{p}^{3} &=10 \\ r_{p} &=(10)^{1 / 3}\\ p_{2}&=r_{p} p_{1} \\ p_{3}&=r_{p} p_{2}=r_{p}^{2} p_{1}=(10)^{2 / 3} \times 100\\ &=464.16 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 In the vapour compression cycle shown in the figure, the evaporating and condensing temperatures are 260 K and 310 K, respectively. The compressor takes in liquid-vapour mixture (state 1) and isentropically compresses it to a dry saturated vapour condition (state 2). The specific heat of the liquid refrigerant is 4.8 kJ/kg-K and may be treated as constant. The enthalpy of evaporation for the refrigerant at 310 K is 1054 kJ/kg. The difference between the enthalpies at state points 1 and 0 (in kJ/kg) is ____________
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{e} &=260 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{c} &=310 \mathrm{K} \\ c_{p l} &=4.8 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ h_{fg} &=1054 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \text { at } T_{c}=310 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking reference temperature T , at which entropy is [latex] s_{T} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad s_{3}-s_{T} &=c \ln \frac{T_{3}}{T} \\ s_{3} &=s_{T}+c \ln \frac{T_{3}}{T}=s_{T}+4.8 \ln \frac{310}{T} \\ \text { Similarly, } s_{0} &=s_{T}+c \ln \frac{260}{T}=s_{T}+4.8 \ln \frac{260}{T} \\ \therefore \quad s_{2}-s_{3} &=\frac{h_{f g}}{T}=\frac{1054}{310} \\ s_{2} &=s_{3}+\frac{1054}{310} \end{aligned}[/latex] Substitute the value of [latex]s_{3}[/latex] in above equation, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} s_{2} &=s_{T}+4.8 \ln \frac{310}{T}+\frac{1054}{310} \\ s_{2} &=s_{1} \\ s_{1} &=s_{T}+4.8 \ln \frac{310}{T}+\frac{1054}{310} \\ h_{1}-h_{0} &=T_{e}\left[s_{1}-s_{0}\right] \\ =& 260 \times\left[s_{T}+4.8 \ln \frac{310}{T}+\frac{1054}{310}\right.\\ &\left.-s_{T}-4.8 \ln \frac{260}{T}\right] \\ &=260\left[4.8 \ln \left(\frac{310}{T} \times \frac{T}{260}\right)+\frac{1054}{310}\right] \\ &1103.51\mathrm{kJ}/\mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 Spot welding of two steel sheets each 2 mm thick is carried out successfully by passing 4 kA of current for 0.2 seconds through the electrodes. The resulting weld nugget formed between the sheets is 5 mm in diameter. Assuming cylindrical shape for the nugget, the thickness of the nugget is________mm.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} t &=2 \mathrm{mm} \\ I &=4 \mathrm{kA} \\ \mathrm{Time} &=0.25 \\ D_{N} &=5 \mathrm{mm} \\ I^{2} R t &=\text { Volume } \times \rho \times \mathrm{H.R} / \mathrm{kg} \\ 4000^{2} \times 200 \times 10^{-6} \times 0.2&=\mathrm{Vol} . \times 8000 \times 1400 \times 10^{3} \\ h&=2.91 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 For an orthogonal cutting operation, tool material is HSS, rake angle is [latex]22^{\circ}[/latex], chip thickness is  0.8 mm, speed is 48 m/min and feed is 0.4 mm/rev. The shear plane angle (in degrees) is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{rl} \alpha=22^{\circ} t_{2}=0.8 & v=48 \quad t_{1}=0.4 \\ r= & t_{1} / t_{2}=0.5 \\ \phi & =\tan ^{-i}\left(\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha}\right) \\ & =\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{0.5 \cos 22^{\circ}}{1-0.5 \sin 22^{\circ}}\right)=29.7^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 50 In a sheet metal of 2 mm thickness a hole of 10 mm diameter needs to be punched. The yield strength in tension of the sheet material is 100 MPa and its ultimate shear strength is 80 MPa. The force required to punch the hole (in kN) is __________
solution: Punching force, [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{\max } &=\pi d t\tau_{\text {pers. }} \\ &=\pi \times 10 \times 2 \times 80=5.024 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 In a single point turning operation with cemented carbide tool and steel work piece, it is found that the Taylor's exponent is 0.25. If the cutting speed is reduced by 50% then the tool life changes by ______ times.

Question 52 Two optically flat plates of glass are kept at a small angle [latex]\theta[/latex]  as shown in the figure.  Monochromatic light is incident vertically. If the wavelength of light used to get a fringe spacing of 1 mm is 450 nm, the wavelength of light (in nm) to get a fringe spacing of 1.5 mm is _________
solution: Given [latex] \begin{aligned} 1 \mathrm{mm} &=450 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Spacing } &=1.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ n &=\frac{2}{\lambda} \quad \text { As given in question }\\ 1.5&=n \times \frac{\lambda_{2}}{2} \\ \lambda_{2}=\frac{1.5 \times 2}{n}&=\frac{1.5 \times 2}{\frac{2}{450}}=1.5 \times 450=675 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 A point P(1,3,-5) is translated by [latex]2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}-4\hat{k}[/latex] and then rotated counter clockwise by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]  about the z-axis. The new position of the point is
solution: Initial point is (1, 3, -5) After tranlated by 2i+3j-4k, it becomes =(1+2, 3+3, -5-4)= (3, 6, -9) Rotation by 90 CCW about z axis (NOTE: : when rotated about z-axis the z component will remain same.) Hence the point (3, 6, -9) changes to (-6, 3, -9).

question: Question 54 The demand for a two-wheeler was 900 units and 1030 units in April 2015 and May 2015, respectively. The forecast for the month of April 2015 was 850 units. Considering a smoothing constant of 0.6, the forecast for the month of June 2015 is

Question 55 A firm uses a turning center, a milling center and a grinding machine to produce two parts. The table below provides the machining time required for each part and the maximum machining time available on each machine. The profit per unit on parts I and II are Rs. 40 and Rs. 100, respectively. The maximum profit per week of the firm is Rs._________
solution: The question will be solved using the graphical method [latex]\text{Maximize } Z=40X_1+100X_2[/latex] Constraints are [latex]\begin{aligned} 12X_1+6X_2 \leq 6000 \\ 4X_1+10X_2 \leq 4000 \\ 2X_1+3X_2 \leq 1800 \\ X_1,X_2 \geq 0 \end{aligned}[/latex] We have three corner points as follow [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{At }(0,400)\;\;\;&Z=40,000\\ \text{At }(375,250)\;\;\;&Z=40,000\\ \text{At }(500,100)\;\;\;&Z=20,000 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, maximum profit per week is 40,000.

question: Question 56 Based on the given statements, select the appropriate option with respect to grammar and usage. Statements i.  The height of Mr. X is 6 feet. ii.  The height of Mr. Y is 5 feet.

options.A: Mr. X is longer than Mr. Y.
options.B: Mr. X is more elongated than Mr. Y.
options.C: Mr. X is taller than Mr. Y.
options.D: Mr. X is lengthier than Mr. Y.

question: Question 57 The students ___________ the teacher on teachers''day for twenty years of dedicated teaching.

Question 58 After India's cricket world cup victory in 1985, Shrotria who was playing both tennis and cricket till then, decided to concentrate only on cricket. And the rest is history What does the  phrase in bold letters mean in this context?

options.B: rest is recorded in history books

question: Question 59 Given [latex](9\text{ inches})^{1/2}=(0.25\text{ yards})^{1/2}[/latex], which one of the following statements is TRUE?

Question 60 S, M, E and F are working in shifts in a team to finish a project. M works with twice the efficiency of others but for half as many days as E worked. S and M have 6 hour shifts in a day, whereas E and F have 12 hours shifts. What is the ratio of contribution of M to contribution of E in the project?
Question 61 The Venn diagram shows the preference of the student population for leisure activities. From the data given,the number of students who like to read books or play sports is______

Question 62 Social science disciplines were in existence in an amorphous form until the colonial period when they were institutionalized. In varying degrees, they were intended to further the colonial interest. In the time of globalization and the economic rise of postcolonial countries like India, conventional ways of knowledge production have become obsolete. Which of the following can be logically inferred from the above statements? i.  Social science disciplines have become obsolete ii.  Social science disciplines had a pre-colonial origin iii. Social science disciplines always promote colonialism
Social science must maintain disciplinary boundaries
Question 63 Two and a quarter hours back, when seen in the mirror, the reflection of the wall clock without number marking seemed to show 1:30. What is the actual current time shown by the clock?

Question 64 M  and N starts from same location.M travels 10 km East then 10 km North-East. N travels 5 km South then 4 km South-East.What is the shortest distance (in km) between M and N at the end of their travel?

Question 65 A wire of length 340 mm is to be cut into two parts. One of the parts is to be made into a square and the other into a rectangle where sides are in the ratio of 1:2. What is the length of the side of the square (in mm) such that the combined area of the square and the rectangle is a MINIMUM?
